Locally Decodable Codes From Nice Subsets of Finite Fields
and Prime Factors of Mersenne Numbers

Kiran S. Kedlaya
MIT
kedlaya@mit.edu    Sergey Yekhanin
MIT
yekhanin@mit.edu
Abstract

A k𝑘k-query Locally Decodable Code (LDC) encodes an n𝑛n-bit message x𝑥x as an N𝑁N-bit codeword C​(x),𝐶𝑥C(x), such that one can probabilistically recover any bit xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} of the message by querying only k𝑘k bits of the codeword C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x), even after some constant fraction of codeword bits has been corrupted. The major goal of LDC related research is to establish the optimal trade-off between length and query complexity of such codes.

Recently [34] introduced a novel technique for constructing locally decodable codes and vastly improved the upper bounds for code length. The technique is based on Mersenne primes. In this paper we extend the work of [34] and argue that further progress via these methods is tied to progress on an old number theory question regarding the size of the largest prime factors of Mersenne numbers.

Specifically, we show that every Mersenne number m=2t−1𝑚superscript2𝑡1m=2^{t}-1 that has a prime factor p>mγ𝑝superscript𝑚𝛾p>m^{\gamma} yields a family of k​(γ)𝑘𝛾k(\gamma)-query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(n1/t).superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp\left(n^{1/t}\right). Conversely, if for some fixed k𝑘k and all ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 one can use the technique of [34] to obtain a family of k𝑘k-query LDCs of length exp⁡(nϵ);superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp\left(n^{\epsilon}\right); then infinitely many Mersenne numbers have prime factors larger than known currently.

1 Introduction

Classical error-correcting codes allow one to encode an n𝑛n-bit string x𝑥x into in N𝑁N-bit codeword C​(x),𝐶𝑥C(x), in such a way that x𝑥x can still be recovered even if C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x) gets corrupted in a number of coordinates. It is well-known that codewords C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x) of length N=O​(n)𝑁𝑂𝑛N=O(n) already suffice to correct errors in up to δ​N𝛿𝑁\delta N locations of C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x) for any constant δ<1/4.𝛿14\delta<1/4. The disadvantage of classical error-correction is that one needs to consider all or most of the (corrupted) codeword to recover anything about x.𝑥x. Now suppose that one is only interested in recovering one or a few bits of x.𝑥x. In such case more efficient schemes are possible. Such schemes are known as locally decodable codes (LDCs). Locally decodable codes allow reconstruction of an arbitrary bit xi,subscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}, from looking only at k𝑘k randomly chosen coordinates of C​(x),𝐶𝑥C(x), where k𝑘k can be as small as 2.22. Locally decodable codes have numerous applications in complexity theory [15, 29], cryptography [6, 11] and the theory of fault tolerant computation [24]. Below is a slightly informal definition of LDCs:

A (k,δ,ϵ)𝑘𝛿italic-ϵ(k,\delta,\epsilon)-locally decodable code encodes n𝑛n-bit strings to N𝑁N-bit codewords C​(x),𝐶𝑥C(x), such that for every i∈[n],𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the bit xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} can be recovered with probability 1−ϵ,1italic-ϵ1-\epsilon, by a randomized decoding procedure that makes only k𝑘k queries, even if the codeword C​(x)𝐶𝑥C(x) is corrupted in up to δ​N𝛿𝑁\delta N locations.

One should think of δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 and ϵ<1/2italic-ϵ12\epsilon<1/2 as constants. The main parameters of interest in LDCs are the length N𝑁N and the query complexity k.𝑘k. Ideally we would like to have both of them as small as possible. The concept of locally decodable codes was explicitly discussed in various papers in the early 1990s [2, 28, 21]. Katz and Trevisan [15] were the first to provide a formal definition of LDCs. Further work on locally decodable codes includes [3, 8, 20, 4, 16, 30, 34, 33, 14, 23].

Below is a brief summary of what was known regarding the length of LDCs prior to [34]. The length of optimal 222-query LDCs was settled by Kerenidis and de Wolf in [16] and is exp⁡(n).𝑛\exp(n).111Throughout the paper we use the standard notation exp⁡(x)=defeO​(x).superscriptdef𝑥superscript𝑒𝑂𝑥\exp(x)\mathbin{\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\rm def}}{{=}}}e^{O(x)}. The best upper bound for the length of 333-query LDCs was exp⁡(n1/2)superscript𝑛12\exp\left(n^{1/2}\right) due to Beimel et al. [3], and the best lower bound is Ω~​(n2)~Ωsuperscript𝑛2\tilde{\Omega}(n^{2}) [33]. For general (constant) k𝑘k the best upper bound was exp⁡(nO​(log⁡log⁡k/(k​log⁡k)))superscript𝑛𝑂𝑘𝑘𝑘\exp\left(n^{O\left(\log\log k/(k\log k)\right)}\right) due to Beimel et al. [4] and the best lower bound is Ω~​(n1+1/(⌈k/2⌉−1))~Ωsuperscript𝑛11𝑘21\tilde{\Omega}\left(n^{1+1/\left(\lceil k/2\rceil-1\right)}\right) [33].

The recent work [34] improved the upper bounds to the extent that it changed the common perception of what may be achievable [12, 11]. [34] introduced a novel technique to construct codes from so-called nice subsets of finite fields and showed that every Mersenne prime p=2t−1𝑝superscript2𝑡1p=2^{t}-1 yields a family of 333-query LDCs of length exp⁡(n1/t).superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp\left(n^{1/t}\right). Based on the largest known Mersenne prime [9], this translates to a length of less than exp⁡(n10−7).superscript𝑛superscript107\exp\left(n^{10^{-7}}\right). Combined with the recursive construction from [4], this result yields vast improvements for all values of k>2.𝑘2k>2. It has often been conjectured that the number of Mersenne primes is infinite. If indeed this conjecture holds, [34] gets three query locally decodable codes of length N=exp⁡(nO​(1log⁡log⁡n))𝑁superscript𝑛𝑂1𝑛N=\exp\left(n^{O\left(\frac{1}{\log\log n}\right)}\right) for infinitely many n.𝑛n. Finally, assuming that the conjecture of Lenstra, Pomerance and Wagstaff [31, 22, 32] regarding the density of Mersenne primes holds, [34] gets three query locally decodable codes of length N=exp⁡(nO​(1log1−ϵ⁡log⁡n))𝑁superscript𝑛𝑂1superscript1italic-ϵ𝑛N=\exp\left(n^{O\left(\frac{1}{\log^{1-\epsilon}\log n}\right)}\right) for all n,𝑛n, for every ϵ>0.italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0.

1.1 Our results

In this paper we address two natural questions left open by [34]:

  1. 1.

    Are Mersenne primes necessary for the constructions of [34]?

  2. 2.

    Has the technique of [34] been pushed to its limits, or one can construct better codes through a more clever choice of nice subsets of finite fields?

We extend the work of [34] and answer both of the questions above. In what follows let P​(m)𝑃𝑚P(m) denote the largest prime factor of m.𝑚m. We show that one does not necessarily need to use Mersenne primes. It suffices to have Mersenne numbers with polynomially large prime factors. Specifically, every Mersenne number m=2t−1𝑚superscript2𝑡1m=2^{t}-1 such that P​(m)≥mγ𝑃𝑚superscript𝑚𝛾P(m)\geq m^{\gamma} yields a family of k​(γ)𝑘𝛾k(\gamma)-query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(n1/t).superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp\left(n^{1/t}\right). A partial converse also holds. Namely, if for some fixed k≥3𝑘3k\geq 3 and all ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 one can use the technique of [34] to (unconditionally) obtain a family of k𝑘k-query LDCs of length exp⁡(nϵ);superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp\left(n^{\epsilon}\right); then for infinitely many t𝑡t we have

P​(2t−1)≥(t/2)1+1/(k−2).𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript𝑡211𝑘2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(t/2)^{1+1/(k-2)}. (1)

The bound (1) may seem quite weak in light of the widely accepted conjecture saying that the number of Mersenne primes is infinite. However (for any k≥3𝑘3k\geq 3) this bound is substantially stronger than what is currently known unconditionally. Lower bounds for P​(2t−1)𝑃superscript2𝑡1P(2^{t}-1) have received a considerable amount of attention in the number theory literature [25, 26, 10, 27, 19, 18]. The strongest result to date is due to Stewart [27]. It says that for all integers t𝑡t ignoring a set of asymptotic density zero, and for all functions ϵ​(t)>0italic-ϵ𝑡0\epsilon(t)>0 where ϵ​(t)italic-ϵ𝑡\epsilon(t) tends to zero monotonically and arbitrarily slowly:

P​(2t−1)>ϵ​(t)​t​(log⁡t)2/log⁡log⁡t.𝑃superscript2𝑡1italic-ϵ𝑡𝑡superscript𝑡2𝑡P(2^{t}-1)>\epsilon(t)t\left(\log t\right)^{2}/\log\log t. (2)

There are no better bounds known to hold for infinitely many values of t,𝑡t, unless one is willing to accept some number theoretic conjectures [19, 18]. We hope that our work will further stimulate the interest in proving lower bounds for P​(2t−1)𝑃superscript2𝑡1P(2^{t}-1) in the number theory community.

In summary, we show that one may be able to improve the unconditional bounds of [34] (say, by discovering a new Mersenne number with a very large prime factor) using the same technique. However any attempts to reach the exp⁡(nϵ)superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp\left(n^{\epsilon}\right) length for some fixed query complexity and all ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 require either progress on an old number theory problem or some radically new ideas.

In this paper we deal only with binary codes for the sake of clarity of presentation. We remark however that our results as well as the results of [34] can be easily generalized to larger alphabets. Such generalization will be discussed in detail in [35].

1.2 Outline

In section 3 we introduce the key concepts of [34], namely that of combinatorial and algebraic niceness of subsets of finite fields. We also briefly review the construction of locally decodable codes from nice subsets. In section 4 we show how Mersenne numbers with large prime factors yield nice subsets of prime fields. In section 5 we prove a partial converse. Namely, we show that every finite field 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q} containing a sufficiently nice subset, is an extension of a prime field 𝔽p,subscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p}, where p𝑝p is a large prime factor of a large Mersenne number. Our main results are summarized in sections 4.3 and 5.4.

3 Nice subsets of finite fields and locally decodable codes

In this section we introduce the key technical concepts of [34], namely that of combinatorial and algebraic niceness of subsets of finite fields. We briefly review the construction of locally decodable codes from nice subsets. Our review is concise although self-contained. We refer the reader interested in a more detailed and intuitive treatment of the construction to the original paper [34]. We start by formally defining locally decodable codes.

Definition 1

A binary code C:{0,1}n→{0,1}N:𝐶→superscript01𝑛superscript01𝑁C:\{0,1\}^{n}\rightarrow\{0,1\}^{N} is said to be (k,δ,ϵ)𝑘𝛿italic-ϵ(k,\delta,\epsilon)-locally decodable if there exists a randomized decoding algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} such that

  1. 1.

    For all x∈{0,1}n,𝑥superscript01𝑛x\in\{0,1\}^{n}, i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] and y∈{0,1}N𝑦superscript01𝑁y\in\{0,1\}^{N} such that dH​(C​(x),y)≤δ​N::subscript𝑑𝐻𝐶𝑥𝑦𝛿𝑁absentd_{H}(C(x),y)\leq\delta N: Pr[𝒜y​(i)=xi]≥1−ϵ,delimited-[]superscript𝒜𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1italic-ϵ[{\mathcal{A}}^{y}(i)=x_{i}]\geq 1-\epsilon, where the probability is taken over the random coin tosses of the algorithm 𝒜.𝒜\mathcal{A}.

  2. 2.

    𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} makes at most k𝑘k queries to y.𝑦y.

We now introduce the concepts of combinatorial and algebraic niceness of subsets of finite fields. Our definitions are syntactically slightly different from the original definitions in [34]. We prefer these formulations since they are more appropriate for the purposes of the current paper. In what follows let 𝔽q∗superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} denote the multiplicative group of 𝔽q.subscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.

Definition 2

A set S⊆𝔽q∗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} is called t𝑡t combinatorially nice if for some constant c>0𝑐0c>0 and every positive integer m𝑚m there exist two n=⌊c​mt⌋𝑛𝑐superscript𝑚𝑡n=\lfloor cm^{t}\rfloor-sized collections of vectors {u1,…,un}subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢𝑛\{u_{1},\ldots,u_{n}\} and {v1,…,vn}subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑛\{v_{1},\ldots,v_{n}\} in 𝔽qm,superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑚\mathbb{F}_{q}^{m}, such that

  • •

    For all i∈[n],𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], (ui,vi)=0;subscript𝑢𝑖subscript𝑣𝑖0(u_{i},v_{i})=0;

  • •

    For all i,j∈[n]𝑖𝑗delimited-[]𝑛i,j\in[n] such that i≠j,𝑖𝑗i\neq j, (uj,vi)∈S.subscript𝑢𝑗subscript𝑣𝑖𝑆(u_{j},v_{i})\in S.

Definition 3

A set S⊆𝔽q∗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} is called k𝑘k algebraically nice if k𝑘k is odd and there exists an odd k′≤ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}\leq k and two sets S0,S1⊆𝔽qsubscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1subscript𝔽𝑞S_{0},S_{1}\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q} such that

  • •

    S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} is not empty;

  • •

    |S1|=k′;subscript𝑆1superscript𝑘′|S_{1}|=k^{\prime};

  • •

    For all α∈𝔽q𝛼subscript𝔽𝑞\alpha\in\mathbb{F}_{q} and β∈S::𝛽𝑆absent\beta\in S: |S0∩(α+β​S1)|≡0mod(2).subscript𝑆0𝛼𝛽subscript𝑆1modulo02\left|S_{0}\cap\left(\alpha+\beta S_{1}\right)\right|\equiv 0\mod(2).

The following lemma shows that for an algebraically nice set S,𝑆S, the set S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} can always be chosen to be large. It is a straightforward generalization of [34, lemma 15].

Lemma 4

Let S⊆𝔽q∗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} be a k𝑘k algebraically nice set. Let S0,S1⊆𝔽qsubscript𝑆0subscript𝑆1subscript𝔽𝑞S_{0},S_{1}\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q} be sets from the definition of algebraic niceness of S.𝑆S. One can always redefine the set S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} to satisfy |S0|≥⌈q/2⌉.subscript𝑆0𝑞2|S_{0}|\geq\lceil q/2\rceil.

  • Proof:   Let L𝐿L be the linear subspace of 𝔽2qsuperscriptsubscript𝔽2𝑞\mathbb{F}_{2}^{q} spanned by the incidence vectors of the sets α+β​S1,𝛼𝛽subscript𝑆1\alpha+\beta S_{1}, for α∈𝔽q𝛼subscript𝔽𝑞\alpha\in\mathbb{F}_{q} and β∈S.𝛽𝑆\beta\in S. Observe that L𝐿L is invariant under the actions of a 111-transitive permutation group (permuting the coordinates in accordance with addition in 𝔽qsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}). This implies that the space L⟂superscript𝐿perpendicular-toL^{\perp} is also invariant under the actions of the same group. Note that L⟂superscript𝐿perpendicular-toL^{\perp} has positive dimension since it contains the incidence vector of the set S0.subscript𝑆0S_{0}. The last two observations imply that L⟂superscript𝐿perpendicular-toL^{\perp} has full support, i.e., for every i∈[q]𝑖delimited-[]𝑞i\in[q] there exists a vector v∈L⟂𝑣superscript𝐿perpendicular-tov\in L^{\perp} such that vi≠0.subscript𝑣𝑖0v_{i}\neq 0. It is easy to verify that any linear subspace of 𝔽2qsuperscriptsubscript𝔽2𝑞\mathbb{F}_{2}^{q} that has full support contains a vector of Hamming weight at least ⌈q/2⌉.𝑞2\lceil q/2\rceil. Let v∈L⟂𝑣superscript𝐿perpendicular-tov\in L^{\perp} be such a vector. Redefining the set S0subscript𝑆0S_{0} to be the set of nonzero coordinates of v𝑣v we conclude the proof.      

We now proceed to the core proposition of [34] that shows how sets exhibiting both combinatorial and algebraic niceness yield locally decodable codes.

Proposition 5

Suppose S⊆𝔽q∗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} is t𝑡t combinatorially nice and k𝑘k algebraically nice; then for every positive integer n𝑛n there exists a code of length exp⁡(n1/t)superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp(n^{1/t}) that is (k,δ,2​k​δ)𝑘𝛿2𝑘𝛿(k,\delta,2k\delta) locally decodable for all δ>0.𝛿0\delta>0.

  • Proof:   Our proof comes in three steps. We specify encoding and local decoding procedures for our codes and then argue the lower bound for the probability of correct decoding. We use the notation from definitions 2 and 3.

    Encoding: We assume that our message has length n=⌊c​mt⌋𝑛𝑐superscript𝑚𝑡n=\lfloor cm^{t}\rfloor for some value of m.𝑚m. (Otherwise we pad the message with zeros. It is easy to see that such padding does not not affect the asymptotic length of the code.) Our code will be linear. Therefore it suffices to specify the encoding of unit vectors e1,…,en,subscript𝑒1…subscript𝑒𝑛e_{1},\ldots,e_{n}, where ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j} has length n𝑛n and a unique non-zero coordinate j.𝑗j. We define the encoding of ejsubscript𝑒𝑗e_{j} to be a qmsuperscript𝑞𝑚q^{m} long vector, whose coordinates are labelled by elements of 𝔽qm.superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑚\mathbb{F}_{q}^{m}. For all w∈𝔽qm𝑤superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑚w\in\mathbb{F}_{q}^{m} we set:

    Enc​(ej)w={1,if (uj,w)∈S0;0,otherwise.Encsubscriptsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑤cases1if (uj,w)∈S0;0otherwise.\mbox{Enc}(e_{j})_{w}=\left\{\begin{array}[]{ll}1,&\mbox{if $(u_{j},w)\in S_{0};$}\\ 0,&\mbox{otherwise.}\\ \end{array}\right. (3)

    It is straightforward to verify that we defined a code encoding n𝑛n bits to exp⁡(n1/t)superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp(n^{1/t}) bits.

    Local decoding: Given a (possibly corrupted) codeword y𝑦y and an index i∈[n],𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], the decoding algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} picks w∈𝔽qm,𝑤superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑚w\in\mathbb{F}_{q}^{m}, such that (ui,w)∈S0subscript𝑢𝑖𝑤subscript𝑆0(u_{i},w)\in S_{0} uniformly at random, reads k′≤ksuperscript𝑘′𝑘k^{\prime}\leq k coordinates of y,𝑦y, and outputs the sum:

    ∑λ∈S1yw+λ​vi.subscript𝜆subscript𝑆1subscript𝑦𝑤𝜆subscript𝑣𝑖\sum\limits_{\lambda\in S_{1}}y_{w+\lambda v_{i}}. (4)

    Probability of correct decoding: First we argue that decoding is always correct if 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} picks w∈𝔽qm𝑤superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑚w\in\mathbb{F}_{q}^{m} such that all bits of y𝑦y in locations {w+λ​vi}λ∈S1subscript𝑤𝜆subscript𝑣𝑖𝜆subscript𝑆1\{w+\lambda v_{i}\}_{\lambda\in S_{1}} are not corrupted. We need to show that for all i∈[n],𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n], x∈{0,1}n𝑥superscript01𝑛x\in\{0,1\}^{n} and w∈𝔽qm,𝑤superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞𝑚w\in\mathbb{F}_{q}^{m}, such that (ui,w)∈S0subscript𝑢𝑖𝑤subscript𝑆0(u_{i},w)\in S_{0}:

    ∑λ∈S1(∑j=1nxj​Enc​(ej))w+λ​vi=xi.subscript𝜆subscript𝑆1subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑗Encsubscript𝑒𝑗𝑤𝜆subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\sum\limits_{\lambda\in S_{1}}\left(\sum\limits_{j=1}^{n}x_{j}\ \mbox{Enc}(e_{j})\right)_{w+\lambda v_{i}}=x_{i}. (5)

All locally decodable codes constructed in this paper are obtained by applying proposition 5 to certain nice sets. 4 Mersenne numbers with large prime factors yield nice subsets of prime fields

4.1 A sufficient condition for the existence of three p𝑝p-th roots of unity summing to zero

Lemma 8

Let p𝑝p be an odd prime. Suppose ord2​(p)<(4/3)​log2⁡p;subscriptord2𝑝43subscript2𝑝\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p)<(4/3)\log_{2}p; then there exist three p𝑝p-th roots of unity in 𝔽¯2subscript¯𝔽2\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{2} that sum to zero.

  • Proof:   We start with a brief review of some basic concepts of projective algebraic geometry. Let 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F} be a field, and f∈𝔽​[x,y,z]𝑓𝔽𝑥𝑦𝑧f\in\mathbb{F}[x,y,z] be a homogeneous polynomial. A triple (x0,y0,z0)∈𝔽3subscript𝑥0subscript𝑦0subscript𝑧0superscript𝔽3(x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})\in\mathbb{F}^{3} is called a zero of f𝑓f if f​(x0,y0,z0)=0.𝑓subscript𝑥0subscript𝑦0subscript𝑧00f(x_{0},y_{0},z_{0})=0. If 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F} is a finite field it makes sense to talk about the number of 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F}-rational points on a curve.

    Let t=ord2​(p).𝑡subscriptord2𝑝t=\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p). Note that Cp⊆𝔽2t.subscript𝐶𝑝subscript𝔽superscript2𝑡C_{p}\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}}. Consider a projective plane Fermat curve χ𝜒\chi defined by

    x(2t−1)/p+y(2t−1)/p+z(2t−1)/p=0.superscript𝑥superscript2𝑡1𝑝superscript𝑦superscript2𝑡1𝑝superscript𝑧superscript2𝑡1𝑝0x^{(2^{t}-1)/p}+y^{(2^{t}-1)/p}+z^{(2^{t}-1)/p}=0. (10)

    |Nq−(q+1)|≤(d−1)​(d−2)​qsubscript𝑁𝑞𝑞1𝑑1𝑑2𝑞\left|N_{q}-(q+1)\right|\leq(d-1)(d-2)\sqrt{q} (11)

    2t+1>(2t−1p−1)​(2t−1p−2)​2t/2+3​2t−1psuperscript2𝑡1superscript2𝑡1𝑝1superscript2𝑡1𝑝2superscript2𝑡23superscript2𝑡1𝑝2^{t}+1>\left(\frac{2^{t}-1}{p}-1\right)\left(\frac{2^{t}-1}{p}-2\right)2^{t/2}+3\frac{2^{t}-1}{p} (12)

    2t+1>(2tp)​(2tp)​2t/2−23​t/2+1p+3∗2tp,superscript2𝑡1superscript2𝑡𝑝superscript2𝑡𝑝superscript2𝑡2superscript23𝑡21𝑝3superscript2𝑡𝑝2^{t}+1>\left(\frac{2^{t}}{p}\right)\left(\frac{2^{t}}{p}\right)2^{t/2}-\frac{2^{3t/2+1}}{p}+\frac{3*2^{t}}{p}, (13)

    and (13) follows from

    2t>22​t+t/2/p2 and 2t/2+1>3.formulae-sequencesuperscript2𝑡superscript22𝑡𝑡2superscript𝑝2 and superscript2𝑡2132^{t}>2^{2t+t/2}/p^{2}\quad\mbox{ and }\quad 2^{t/2+1}>3.

    Now note that the first inequality above follows from t<(4/3)​log2⁡p𝑡43subscript2𝑝t<(4/3)\log_{2}p and the second follows from t>1.𝑡1t>1.      

Note that the constant 4/3434/3 in lemma 8 cannot be improved to 2: there are no three elements of C13264529subscript𝐶13264529C_{13264529} that sum to zero, even though ord2​(13264529)=47<2∗log2⁡13264529≈47.3.subscriptord213264529472subscript21326452947.3\mathrm{ord}_{2}(13264529)=47<2*\log_{2}13264529\approx 47.3.

4.2 A sufficient condition for the existence of k𝑘k p𝑝p-th roots of unity summing to zero

Our argument in this section comes in three steps. First we briefly review the notion of (additive) Fourier coefficients of subsets of 𝔽2t.subscript𝔽superscript2𝑡\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}}. Next, we invoke a folklore argument to show that subsets of 𝔽2tsubscript𝔽superscript2𝑡\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}} with appropriately small nontrivial Fourier coefficients contain k𝑘k-tuples of elements that sum to zero. Finally, we use a recent result of Bourgain and Chang [5] (generalizing the classical estimate for Gauss sums) to argue that (under certain constraints on p𝑝p) all nontrivial Fourier coefficients of Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p} are small.

For x∈𝔽2t𝑥subscript𝔽superscript2𝑡x\in\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}} let T​r​(x)=x+x2+…+x2t−1𝑇𝑟𝑥𝑥superscript𝑥2…superscript𝑥superscript2𝑡1Tr(x)=x+x^{2}+\ldots+x^{2^{t-1}} denote the trace of x.𝑥x. It is not hard to verify that for all x,𝑥x, T​r​(x)∈𝔽2.𝑇𝑟𝑥subscript𝔽2Tr(x)\in\mathbb{F}_{2}. Characters of 𝔽2tsubscript𝔽superscript2𝑡\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}} are homomorphisms from the additive group of 𝔽2tsubscript𝔽superscript2𝑡\mathbb{F}_{2^{t}} into the multiplicative group {±1}.plus-or-minus1\{\pm 1\}. There exist 2tsuperscript2𝑡2^{t} characters. 4.3 Summary

In this section we summarize our positive results and show that one does not necessarily need to use Mersenne primes to construct locally decodable codes via the methods of [34]. It suffices to have Mersenne numbers with polynomially large prime factors. Recall that P​(m)𝑃𝑚P(m) denotes the largest prime factor of an integer m.𝑚m. Our first theorem gets 333-query LDCs from Mersenne numbers m𝑚m with prime factors larger than m3/4.superscript𝑚34m^{3/4}.

Theorem 12

Suppose P​(2t−1)>20.75​t;𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript20.75𝑡P(2^{t}-1)>2^{0.75t}; then for every message length n𝑛n there exists a three query locally decodable code of length exp⁡(n1/t).superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp(n^{1/t}).

  • Proof:   Let P​(2t−1)=p.𝑃superscript2𝑡1𝑝P(2^{t}-1)=p. Observe that p| 2t−1conditional𝑝superscript2𝑡1p\ |\ 2^{t}-1 and p>20.75​t𝑝superscript20.75𝑡p>2^{0.75t} yield ord2​(p)<(4/3)​log2⁡p.subscriptord2𝑝43subscript2𝑝\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p)<(4/3)\log_{2}p. Combining lemmas 8,7 and 6 with proposition 5 we obtain the statement of the theorem.      

As an example application of theorem 12 one can observe that P​(223−1)=178481>2(3/4)∗23≈155872𝑃superscript2231178481superscript23423155872P(2^{23}-1)=178481>2^{(3/4)*23}\approx 155872 yields a family of three query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(n1/23).superscript𝑛123\exp(n^{1/23}). Theorem 12 immediately yields:

Theorem 13

Suppose for infinitely many t𝑡t we have P​(2t−1)>20.75​t;𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript20.75𝑡P(2^{t}-1)>2^{0.75t}; then for every ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 there exists a family of three query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(nϵ).superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp(n^{\epsilon}).

The next theorem gets constant query LDCs from Mersenne numbers m𝑚m with prime factors larger than mγsuperscript𝑚𝛾m^{\gamma} for every value of γ.𝛾\gamma.

Theorem 14

For every γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 there exists an odd integer k=k​(γ)𝑘𝑘𝛾k=k(\gamma) such that the following implication holds. Suppose P​(2t−1)>2γ​t;𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript2𝛾𝑡P(2^{t}-1)>2^{\gamma t}; then for every message length n𝑛n there exists a k𝑘k query locally decodable code of length exp⁡(n1/t).superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp(n^{1/t}).

  • Proof:   Let P​(2t−1)=p.𝑃superscript2𝑡1𝑝P(2^{t}-1)=p. Observe that p| 2t−1conditional𝑝superscript2𝑡1p\ |\ 2^{t}-1 and p>2γ​t𝑝superscript2𝛾𝑡p>2^{\gamma t} yield ord2​(p)<(1/γ)​log2⁡p.subscriptord2𝑝1𝛾subscript2𝑝\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p)<(1/\gamma)\log_{2}p. Combining lemmas 22,7 and 6 with proposition 5 we obtain the statement of the theorem.      

As an immediate corollary we get:

Theorem 15

Suppose for some γ>0𝛾0\gamma>0 and infinitely many t𝑡t we have P​(2t−1)>2γ​t;𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript2𝛾𝑡P(2^{t}-1)>2^{\gamma t}; then there is a fixed k𝑘k such that for every ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 there exists a family of k𝑘k query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(nϵ).superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp(n^{\epsilon}).

5 Nice subsets of finite fields yield Mersenne numbers with large prime factors

Definition 16

We say that a sequence {Si⊆𝔽qi∗}i≥1subscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖superscriptsubscript𝔽subscript𝑞𝑖𝑖1\left\{S_{i}\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q_{i}}^{*}\right\}_{i\geq 1} of subsets of finite fields is k𝑘k-nice if every Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i} is k𝑘k algebraically nice and t​(i)𝑡𝑖t(i) combinatorially nice, for some integer valued monotonically increasing function t.𝑡t.

The core proposition 5 asserts that a subset S⊆𝔽q∗𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*} that is k𝑘k algebraically nice and t𝑡t combinatorially nice yields a family of k𝑘k-query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(n1/t).superscript𝑛1𝑡\exp(n^{1/t}). Clearly, to get k𝑘k-query LDCs of length exp⁡(nϵ)superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp(n^{\epsilon}) for some fixed k𝑘k and every ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 via this proposition, one needs to exhibit a k𝑘k-nice sequence. In this section we show how the existence of a k𝑘k-nice sequence implies that infinitely many Mersenne numbers have large prime factors. Our argument proceeds in two steps. First we show that a k𝑘k-nice sequence yields an infinite sequence of primes {pi}i≥1,subscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑖1\left\{p_{i}\right\}_{i\geq 1}, where every Cpisubscript𝐶subscript𝑝𝑖C_{p_{i}} contains a k𝑘k-tuple of elements summing to zero. Next we show that Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p} contains a short additive dependence only if p𝑝p is a large factor of a Mersenne number.

5.1 A nice sequence yields infinitely many primes p𝑝p with short dependencies between p𝑝p-th roots of unity

Let ΓΓ\Gamma be a family of subsets of 𝔽q.subscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}.   • Proof:   Let 𝐮=(u1,…,uh)𝐮subscript𝑢1…subscript𝑢ℎ{\bf u}=(u_{1},\ldots,u_{h}) and 𝐯=(v1,…,vh).𝐯subscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣ℎ{\bf v}=(v_{1},\ldots,v_{h}). The next lemma bounds combinatorial niceness of certain subsets of 𝔽q∗.superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*}.

Lemma 20

Let 𝔽q=𝔽pl,subscript𝔽𝑞subscript𝔽superscript𝑝𝑙\mathbb{F}_{q}=\mathbb{F}_{p^{l}}, where p𝑝p is prime. Let S⊆𝔽q∗.𝑆superscriptsubscript𝔽𝑞S\subseteq\mathbb{F}_{q}^{*}. The next lemma presents the main result of this section.

Lemma 21

Let k𝑘k be an odd integer. Suppose there exists a k𝑘k-nice sequence; then for infinitely many primes p𝑝p some k𝑘k of elements of Cpsubscript𝐶𝑝C_{p} add up to zero.

In what follows we present necessary conditions for the existence of k𝑘k-tuples of p𝑝p-th roots of unity in 𝔽¯2subscript¯𝔽2\overline{\mathbb{F}}_{2} that sum to zero. 5.3 A necessary condition for the existence of three p𝑝p-th roots of unity summing to zero

    We next check that there cannot be two distinct nonzero pairs (a,b),(a′,b′)𝑎𝑏superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′(a,b),(a^{\prime},b^{\prime}) with πa,b=πa′,b′=1subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏subscript𝜋superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′1\pi_{a,b}=\pi_{a^{\prime},b^{\prime}}=1. The equations πa,b=1subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏1\pi_{a,b}=1 and πa′−a,b′−b=1subscript𝜋superscript𝑎′𝑎superscript𝑏′𝑏1\pi_{a^{\prime}-a,b^{\prime}-b}=1 force a+b≥t𝑎𝑏𝑡a+b\geq t and (a′−a)+(b′−b)≥tsuperscript𝑎′𝑎superscript𝑏′𝑏𝑡(a^{\prime}-a)+(b^{\prime}-b)\geq t, so a′+b′≥2​tsuperscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′2𝑡a^{\prime}+b^{\prime}\geq 2t. But a′,b′≤t−1superscript𝑎′superscript𝑏′𝑡1a^{\prime},b^{\prime}\leq t-1, contradiction.

    If there is no nonzero pair (a,b)𝑎𝑏(a,b) with 0≤a,b≤t−1formulae-sequence0𝑎𝑏𝑡10\leq a,b\leq t-1 and πa,b=1subscript𝜋𝑎𝑏1\pi_{a,b}=1, then all πi,jsubscript𝜋𝑖𝑗\pi_{i,j} are distinct, so p≥t2𝑝superscript𝑡2p\geq t^{2}. Otherwise, as above, the pair (a,b)𝑎𝑏(a,b) is unique, and the pairs (i,j)𝑖𝑗(i,j) with 0≤i,j≤t−1formulae-sequence0𝑖𝑗𝑡10\leq i,j\leq t-1 and (i,j)≱(a,b)not-greater-than-or-equals𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑏(i,j)\not\geq(a,b) are pairwise distinct. The number of pairs excluded by the condition (i,j)≱(a,b)not-greater-than-or-equals𝑖𝑗𝑎𝑏(i,j)\not\geq(a,b) is (t−a)​(t−b)𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑏(t-a)(t-b); since a+b≥t𝑎𝑏𝑡a+b\geq t, (t−a)​(t−b)≤t2/4𝑡𝑎𝑡𝑏superscript𝑡24(t-a)(t-b)\leq t^{2}/4. Hence p≥t2−t2/4=3​t2/4𝑝superscript𝑡2superscript𝑡243superscript𝑡24p\geq t^{2}-t^{2}/4=3t^{2}/4 as desired.      

While the necessary condition given by lemma 23 is quite far away from the sufficient condition given by lemma 8, it nonetheless suffices for checking that for most primes p𝑝p, there do not exist three p𝑝p-th roots of unity summing to zero. For instance, among the 664578 odd primes p≤108𝑝superscript108p\leq 10^{8}, all but 550 are ruled out by Lemma 23. (There is an easy argument that t𝑡t must be odd if p>3𝑝3p>3; this cuts the list down to 273 primes.) Each remaining p𝑝p can be tested by computing gcd​(xp+1,(x+1)p+1)gcdsuperscript𝑥𝑝1superscript𝑥1𝑝1\mathrm{gcd}(x^{p}+1,(x+1)^{p}+1); the only examples we found that did not satisfy the condition of lemma 8 were (p,t)=(73,9),(262657,27),(599479,33),(121369,39).𝑝𝑡739262657275994793312136939(p,t)=(73,9),(262657,27),(599479,33),(121369,39).

5.4 Summary

In the beginning of this section 5 we argued that in order to use the method of [34], (i.e., proposition 5) to obtain k𝑘k-query locally decodable codes of length exp⁡(nϵ)superscript𝑛italic-ϵ\exp(n^{\epsilon}) for some fixed k𝑘k and all ϵ>0,italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, one needs to exhibit a k𝑘k-nice sequence of subsets of finite fields. In what follows we use technical results of the previous subsections to show that the existence of a k𝑘k-nice sequence implies that infinitely many Mersenne numbers have large prime factors.

Theorem 24

Let k𝑘k be odd. Suppose there exists a k𝑘k-nice sequence of subsets of finite fields; then for infinitely many values of t𝑡t we have

P​(2t−1)≥(t/2)1+1/(k−2).𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript𝑡211𝑘2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(t/2)^{1+1/(k-2)}. (40)

  • Proof:   Using lemmas 21 and 22 we conclude that a k𝑘k-nice sequence yields infinitely many primes p𝑝p such that ord2​(p)≤2​p1−1/(k−1).subscriptord2𝑝2superscript𝑝11𝑘1\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p)\leq 2p^{1-1/(k-1)}. Let p𝑝p be such a prime and t=ord2​(p).𝑡subscriptord2𝑝t=\mathrm{ord}_{2}(p). Then P​(2t−1)≥(t/2)1+1/(k−2).𝑃superscript2𝑡1superscript𝑡211𝑘2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(t/2)^{1+1/(k-2)}.      

A combination of lemmas 21 and 23 yields a slightly stronger bound for the special case of 333-nice sequences.

Theorem 25

Suppose there exists a 333-nice sequence of subsets; then for infinitely many values of t𝑡t we have

P​(2t−1)≥(3/4)​t2.𝑃superscript2𝑡134superscript𝑡2P(2^{t}-1)\geq(3/4)t^{2}. (41)

We would like to remind the reader that although the lower bounds for P​(2t−1)𝑃superscript2𝑡1P(2^{t}-1) given by (40) and (41) are extremely weak light of the widely accepted conjecture saying that the number of Mersenne primes is infinite, they are substantially stronger than what is currently known unconditionally (2).

6 Conclusion

Recently [34] came up with a novel technique for constructing locally decodable codes and obtained vast improvements upon the earlier work. The construction proceeds in two steps. First [34] shows that if there exist subsets of finite fields with certain ’nice’ properties then there exist good codes. Next [34] constructs nice subsets of prime fields 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} for Mersenne primes p𝑝p.

In this paper we have undertaken an in-depth study of nice subsets of general finite fields. We have shown that constructing nice subsets is closely related to proving lower bounds on the size of largest prime factors of Mersenne numbers. Specifically we extended the constructions of [34] to obtain nice subsets of prime fields 𝔽psubscript𝔽𝑝\mathbb{F}_{p} for primes p𝑝p that are large factors of Mersenne numbers. This implies that strong lower bounds for size of the largest prime factors of Mersenne numbers yield better locally decodable codes. Conversely, we argued that if one can obtain codes of subexponential length and constant query complexity through nice subsets of finite fields then infinitely many Mersenne numbers have prime factors larger than known currently.
